I have a sequence of maths PR written while travelling to and from a conference, that I would like to get in, but they seem to be slipping down the #queue. :-)

  • #13136 simp lemmas about the associator in Type
  • #13310 cleanup of CategoryTheory/Monoidal/Mon_
  • #13316 cleanup of CategoryTheory/Monoidal/Comon_
  • #13315 cleanup of CoalgebraCat
  • #13312 oplax functors and comonoids (depends on both #13310 and #13316)
  • #13313 the convolution monoid between a monoid and a comonoid (depends on #13316)
  • #13317 Hopf monoids, containing three results (antipode is an antihom, morphisms interwine antipodes, S^2 = id in a commutative Hopf monoid) which in fact haven't been proved yet for honest Hopf algebras! (depends on all the above)
Adding the t-category-theory tag may facilitate the process...

antipode is an antihom

Nice! I remember having to prove that as an exercise, and it's quite a lot of steps. I could only figure it out with string diagrams (I have no idea how people can figure these things out with Sweedler notation). The proof in the PR is just as complicated as I remember — I like the ascii art in the PR to keep track of it all.
We need to get Jamie Vicary here, and have this horrible proof (the proof is not horrible, just how it is written in Lean) provoke him into thinking about Lean/globular integration.
Jamie is my friend's advisor, Let me use my connections, eheh
Excellent. I've talked to him about it years ago, but we need to have him hearing about it from all sides. :-)

Kyle Miller said:

The proof in the PR is just as complicated as I remember — I like the ascii art in the PR to keep track of it all.

Could you link to those lines?
Are calc blocks for ascii-art something we want, or is that going in the wrong direction and this should all be displayed in widgets?

Note that the ASCII art here represents the just the first term in such a calc block. The actual calculation is a sequence of transformations of this 3d diagram, represented in the doc-string by the terse paragraph below the diagram.

In an ideal world, the proof should be an inscrutable term, wrapped in something that displays (and it is editable) in an embedded instance of homotopy.io running in the InfoView.

In fact, I only saw this now, but the paper https://arxiv.org/pdf/2402.13179 about this year's edition of homotopy.io includes an appendix which does the "antipode is an antihom" proof. The proof is contained in https://beta.homotopy.io/p/2402.00006. Sadly you can't seem to hyperlink to particular places?? The statement is just labelled "Lemma", after the "Hopf algebra" folder, and the proof follows it.

Sadly in my view homotopy.io as is is currently useless (sorry Jamie!!) because you have to build everything up from scratch. This file contains the definition of a hopf algebra from the beginning. There's no way to separate properly your hypotheses and definitions from your proofs, and I've never understood why the homotopy.io developers think this is a good thing. (It's a clever and amusing fact that statements and proofs and the objects in the statements are all just cells at different levels, but somehow this clever observation seems to have derailed the project from being usable as a proof assistant.)

If we could have modular projects that defined "this is a hopf algebra", "this is a morphism", and so on, then we could begin integrating with Lean, and actually get somewhere. :-)
After reading through some of the suggestions, would it be helpful to have a feature in homotopy.io where it is possible to hyperlink particular parts rather than just the proof as a whole?
I mean, that would be an improvement, but not really address the basic problem of not having "importable definitions".
